eng: "That's the reason they're called lessons," the Gryphon remarked: "because they lessen from day to day."
fr: << C'est pour cela qu'on les appelle lecons, >> dit le Griffon, << parce que nous les laissons la peu a peu.

eng: This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark.
fr: >> C'etait la pour Alice une idee toute nouvelle ; elle y reflechit un peu avant de faire une autre observation.

eng: "Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?"
fr: << Alors le onzieme jour devait etre un jour de conge ?

eng: "Of course it was," said the Mock Turtle.
fr: >> << Assurement, >> repondit la Fausse-Tortue.

eng: "Two lines!" cried the Mock Turtle.
fr: << On forme deux rangs, >> cria la Fausse-Tortue :

eng: "Why," said the Gryphon, "you first form into a line along the sea-shore--"
fr: << D'abord, >> dit le Griffon, << on se met en rang le long des bords de la mer -- >>

eng: "What sort of a dance is it?"
fr: << Qu'est-ce que c'est que cette danse-la ? >>

eng: "No, indeed," said Alice.
fr: << Non, vraiment, >> dit Alice.

eng: "--so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!"
fr: << De sorte que vous ne pouvez pas du tout vous figurer quelle chose delicieuse c'est qu'un quadrille de homards. >>

eng: (Alice began to say "I once tasted--" but checked herself hastily, and said "No, never")
fr: (Alice allait dire : << J'en ai goute une fois -- >> mais elle se reprit vivement, et dit : << Non, jamais. >>)

eng: "--and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster--"
fr: << et peut-etre ne vous a-t-on jamais presentee a un homard ? >>

eng: ("I haven't," said Alice)
fr: -- ( << Non, >> dit Alice)

eng: At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:--
fr: Enfin la Fausse-Tortue retrouva la voix, et, tandis que de grosses larmes coulaient le long de ses joues, elle continua :

eng: "Same as if he had a bone in his throat," said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back.
fr: << On dirait qu'elle a un os dans le gosier, >> dit le Griffon, et il se mit a la secouer et a lui taper dans le dos.

eng: He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice.
fr: Elle regarda Alice et s'efforca de parler, mais les sanglots etoufferent sa voix pendant une ou deux minutes.

eng: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes.
fr: La Fausse-Tortue soupira profondement et passa le dos d'une de ses nageoires sur ses yeux.

eng: CHAPTER X. The Lobster Quadrille
fr: CHAPITRE X. LE QUADRILLE DE HOMARDS.

eng: "And how did you manage on the twelfth?" Alice went on eagerly.
fr: '<< Et comment vous arrangiez-vous le douzieme jour ? >> s'empressa de demander Alice.

eng: "Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you've cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way--"
fr: des phoques, des tortues et des saumons, et ainsi de suite. Puis lorsqu'on a debarrasse la cote des gelees de mer -- >>

eng: "You may not have lived much under the sea--"
fr: << Peut-etre n'avez-vous pas beaucoup vecu au fond de la mer ? >>

eng: "_That_ generally takes some time," interrupted the Gryphon.
fr: << Cela prend ordinairement longtemps, >> dit le Griffon.

eng: "That's enough about lessons," the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: "tell her something about the games now."
fr: << En voila assez sur les lecons, >> dit le Griffon intervenant d'un ton tres-decide ; << parlez-lui des jeux maintenant. >>

eng: "Each with a lobster as a partner!" cried the Gryphon.
fr: << Chacun ayant un homard pour danseur, >> cria le Griffon.

eng: "The reason is," said the Gryphon, "that they _would_ go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn't get them out again. That's all."
fr: << La raison, c'est que les merlans, >> dit le Griffon, << voulurent absolument aller a la danse avec les homards. Alors on les jeta a la mer. Alors ils eurent a tomber bien loin, bien loin. Alors ils s'entrerent la queue fortement dans la bouche. Alors ils ne purent plus l'en retirer. Voila tout. >>

eng: "Thank you," said Alice, "it's very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before."
fr: << Merci, >> dit Alice, << c'est tres-interessant ; je n'en avais jamais tant appris sur le compte des merlans. >>

eng: "I can tell you more than that, if you like," said the Gryphon.
fr: << Je propose donc, >> dit le Griffon, << que vous nous racontiez quelques-unes de vos aventures. >>

eng: " --you advance twice--"
fr: << --on avance deux fois -- >>

eng: "I never thought about it," said Alice. "Why?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "_It does the boots and shoes_," the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Alice was thoroughly puzzled.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Does the boots and shoes!" she repeated in a wondering tone.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Why, what are _your_ shoes done with?" said the Gryphon.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I mean, what makes them so shiny?" Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer. "They're done with blacking, I believe."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You're wrong about the crumbs," said the Mock Turtle: "crumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they _have_ their tails in their mouths; and the reason is--" here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.--"Tell her about the reason and all that," he said to the Gryphon.
fr: << Vous vous trompez a l'endroit de la mie de pain, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue : << la mie serait enlevee dans la mer, mais ils ont bien la queue dans la bouche, et la raison en est que -- >> Ici la Fausse-Tortue bailla et ferma les yeux. << Dites-lui-en la raison et tout ce qui s'ensuit, >> dit-elle au Griffon.

eng: "Boots and shoes under the sea," the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, "are done with a whiting. Now you know."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Soles and eels, of course," the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: "any shrimp could have told you that."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "If I'd been the whiting," said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, "I'd have said to the porpoise, 'Keep back, please: we don't want _you_ with us!'"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "They were obliged to have him with them," the Mock Turtle said: "no wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Wouldn't it really?" said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Of course not," said the Mock Turtle: "why, if a fish came to _me_, and told me he was going a journey, I should say 'With what porpoise?'"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Don't you mean 'purpose'?" said Alice.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I mean what I say," the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added "Come, let's hear some of _your_ adventures."
fr: << I mean what I say, >> the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added "Come, let's hear some of _your_ adventures."

eng: "I could tell you my adventures--beginning from this morning," said Alice a little timidly: "but it's no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then."
fr: << Je pourrais vous conter mes aventures a partir de ce matin, >> dit Alice un peu timidement ; << mais il est inutile de parler de la journee d'hier, car j'etais une personne tout a fait differente alors. >>

eng: "Explain all that," said the Mock Turtle.
fr: << Expliquez-nous cela, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue.

eng: "No, no! The adventures first," said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: "explanations take such a dreadful time."'
fr: << Non, non, les aventures d'abord, >> dit le Griffon d'un ton d'impatience ; << les explications prennent tant de temps.

eng: "And what are they made of?" Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I believe so," Alice replied thoughtfully. "They have their tails in their mouths--and they're all over crumbs."
fr: << Je le crois, >> repliqua Alice, en se recueillant. << Ils ont la queue dans la bouche -- et sont tout couverts de mie de pain. >>

eng: "Do you know why it's called a whiting?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Yes," said Alice, "I've often seen them at dinn--" she checked herself hastily.
fr: << Oui, >> dit Alice, << je les ai souvent vus a di-- >> elle s'arreta tout court.

eng: "Of course," the Mock Turtle said: "advance twice, set to partners--"
fr: << Cela va sans dire, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue. << Avancez deux fois et balancez -- >>

eng: "--change lobsters, and retire in same order," continued the Gryphon.
fr: << Changez de homards, et revenez dans le meme ordre, >> continua le Griffon.

eng: "Then, you know," the Mock Turtle went on, "you throw the--"
fr: << Et puis, vous comprenez, >> continua la Fausse-Tortue, << vous jetez les -- >>

eng: "The lobsters!" shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
fr: << Les homards ! >> cria le Griffon, en faisant un bond en l'air.

eng: " --as far out to sea as you can--"
fr: << --aussi loin a la mer que vous le pouvez -- >>

eng: "I don't know where Dinn may be," said the Mock Turtle, "but if you've seen them so often, of course you know what they're like."
fr: << Je ne sais pas ou est Di, >> reprit la Fausse Tortue ; << mais, puisque vous les avez vus si souvent, vous devez savoir l'air qu'ils ont ? >>

eng: "Turn a somersault in the sea!" cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.
fr: << --vous faites une cabriole dans la mer ! ~~~ !! >> cria la Fausse-Tortue, en cabriolant de tous cotes comme une folle.

eng: "Change lobsters again!" yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
fr: << Changez encore de homards ! ~~~ !!! >> hurla le Griffon de toutes ses forces.

eng: "Back to land again, and that's all the first figure," said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
fr: << --revenez a terre ; et -- c'est la la premiere figure, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue, baissant tout a coup la voix ; et ces deux etres, qui pendant tout ce temps avaient bondi de tous cotes comme des fous, se rassirent bien tristement et bien posement, puis regarderent Alice.

eng: "It must be a very pretty dance," said Alice timidly.
fr: << Cela doit etre une tres-jolie danse, >> dit timidement Alice.

eng: "Would you like to see a little of it?" said the Mock Turtle.
fr: << Voudriez-vous voir un peu comment ca se danse ? >> dit la Fausse-Tortue.

eng: "Swim after them!" screamed the Gryphon.
fr: << Vous nagez a leur poursuite ! ! ~~~ >> cria le Griffon.

eng: "Come, let's try the first figure!" said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon.
fr: << Allons, essayons la premiere figure, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue au Griffon ;

eng: "Very much indeed," said Alice.
fr: << Cela me ferait grand plaisir, >> dit Alice.

eng: "Oh, as to the whiting," said the Mock Turtle, "they--you've seen them, of course?"
fr: << Oh ! quant aux merlans, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue, << ils -- vous les avez vus, sans doute ? >>

eng: "Thank you, it's a very interesting dance to watch," said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: "and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!"
fr: << Merci ; c'est une danse tres-interessante a voir danser, >> dit Alice, enchantee que ce fut enfin fini ; << et je trouve cette curieuse chanson du merlan si agreable ! >>

eng: "But the snail replied "Too far, too far!" and gave a look askance-- Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You can really have no notion how delightful it will be When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "What matters it how far we go?" his scaly friend replied. "There is another shore, you know, upon the other side. The further off from England the nearer is to France-- Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance. Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance? Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Will you walk a little faster?" said a whiting to a snail.
fr: << Nous n'irons plus a l'eau, Si tu n'avances tot ; Ce Marsouin trop presse Va tous nous ecraser. Colimacon danse, Entre dans la danse ; Sautons, dansons, Avant de faire un plongeon. >>

eng: So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:--
fr: Ils se mirent donc a danser gravement tout autour d'Alice, lui marchant de temps a autre sur les pieds quand ils approchaient trop pres, et remuant leurs pattes de devant pour marquer la mesure, tandis que la Fausse-Tortue chantait tres-lentement et tres-tristement :

eng: "Oh, _you_ sing," said the Gryphon. "I've forgotten the words."
fr: << Oh ! chantez, vous, >> dit le Griffon ; << moi j'ai oublie les paroles. >>

eng: "We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?"
fr: << nous pouvons la faire sans homards, vous comprenez. Qui va chanter ? ~~~ >>

eng: "There's a porpoise close behind us, and he's treading on my tail. See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance! They are waiting on the shingle--will you come and join the dance? Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance? Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?"
fr: << Je ne veux pas danser, Je me f'rais fracasser. >> << Oh ! ~~~ >> reprend le Merlan, << C'est pourtant bien plaisant. >> Colimacon danse, Entre dans la danse ; Sautons, dansons, Avant de faire un plongeon. << Je ne veux pas plonger, Je ne sais pas nager. >> -- << Le Homard et l'bateau D'sauv'tag' te tir'ront d'l'eau. >> Colimacon danse, Entre dans la danse ; Sautons, dansons, Avant de faire un plongeon.

eng: So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit.
fr: >> Alice commenca donc a leur conter ses aventures depuis le moment ou elle avait vu le Lapin Blanc pour la premiere fois.

eng: She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so _very_ wide, but she gained courage as she went on.
fr: Elle fut d'abord un peu troublee dans le commencement ; les deux creatures se tenaient si pres d'elle, une de chaque cote, et ouvraient de si grands yeux et une si grande bouche ! ~~~ Mais elle reprenait courage a mesure qu'elle parlait.

eng: Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating "_You are old, Father William_," to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said "That's very curious."
fr: Les auditeurs resterent fort tranquilles jusqu'a ce qu'elle arrivat au moment de son histoire ou elle avait eu a repeter a la chenille : << Vous etes vieux, Pere Guillaume, >> et ou les mots lui etaient venus tout de travers, et alors la Fausse-Tortue poussa un long soupir et dit : << C'est bien singulier.

eng: "It's all about as curious as it can be," said the Gryphon.
fr: >> << Tout cela est on ne peut plus singulier, >> dit le Griffon.

eng: "How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!"
fr: << Comme ces etres-la vous commandent et vous font repeter des lecons !'

eng: the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully.
fr: repeta la Fausse-Tortue d'un air reveur.

eng: "Stand up and repeat ''_Tis the voice of the sluggard_,'"
fr: << Debout, et recitez : << C'est la voix du canon, >>

eng: He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
fr: Elle regardait le Griffon comme si elle lui croyait de l'autorite sur Alice.

eng: Tell her to begin."
fr: Dites-lui de s'y mettre. >>

eng: "I should like to hear her try and repeat something now.
fr: << Je voudrais bien l'entendre reciter quelque chose a present.

eng: "It all came different!"
fr: "<< Tout de travers, >>"

eng: said the Gryphon.
fr: dit le Griffon.

eng: thought Alice; "I might as well be at school at once."
fr: >> pensa Alice ; << autant vaudrait etre a l'ecole.

eng: "That's different from what _I_ used to say when I was a child," said the Gryphon.
fr: << C'est tout different de ce que je recitais quand j'etais petit, moi, >> dit le Griffon.

eng: However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:--
fr: Cependant elle se leva et se mit a reciter ; mais elle avait la tete si pleine du Quadrille de Homards, qu'elle savait a peine ce qu'elle disait, et que les mots lui venaient tout drolement : --

eng: "'Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare, "You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair."
fr: << C'est la voix du homard grondant comme la foudre : << On m'a trop fait bouillir, il faut que je me poudre ! >>

eng: As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes."
fr: Puis, les pieds en dehors, prenant la brosse en main, De se faire bien beau vite il se met en train. >>

eng: [later editions continued as follows When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark, And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark, But, when the tide rises and sharks are around, His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.]
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well, I never heard it before," said the Mock Turtle; "but it sounds uncommon nonsense."
fr: << Je ne l'avais pas encore entendu reciter, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue ; << mais cela me fait l'effet d'un fameux galimatias.

eng: Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would _ever_ happen in a natural way again.
fr: >> Alice ne dit rien ; elle s'etait rassise, la figure dans ses mains, se demandant avec etonnement si jamais les choses reprendraient leur cours naturel.

eng: "I should like to have it explained," said the Mock Turtle.
fr: << Je voudrais bien qu'on m'expliquat cela, >> dit la Fausse-Tortue.

eng: "How _could_ he turn them out with his nose, you know?"
fr: "<< Pourquoi dire qu'il avait les pieds en dehors ? >>

eng: "Go on with the next verse."
fr: "<< Continuez, recitez les vers suivants. >>

eng: "But about his toes?" the Mock Turtle persisted.
fr: "<< Mais, les pieds en dehors, >> continua opiniatrement la Fausse-Tortue.

eng: "She can't explain it," said the Gryphon hastily.
fr: "<< Elle ne peut pas l'expliquer, >> dit le Griffon vivement.

eng: "What _is_ the use of repeating all that stuff," the Mock Turtle interrupted, "if you don't explain it as you go on? It's by far the most confusing thing _I_ ever heard!"
fr: "<< A quoi bon repeter tout ce galimatias, >> interrompit la Fausse-Tortue, << si vous ne l'expliquez pas a mesure que vous le dites ? C'est, de beaucoup, ce que j'ai entendu de plus embrouillant.

eng: Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:-- "I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye, How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie--" [later editions continued as follows The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat, While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat. When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon, Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon: While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl, And concluded the banquet--]
fr: Alice n'osa pas desobeir, bien qu'elle fut sure que les mots allaient lui venir tout de travers. Elle continua donc d'une voix tremblante : << Passant pres de chez lui, j'ai vu, ne vous deplaise, Une huitre et un hibou qui dinaient fort a l'aise. ~~~ >>

eng: "Go on with the next verse," the Gryphon repeated impatiently: "it begins '_I passed by his garden_.'"
fr: "<< Recitez les vers suivants, >> repeta le Griffon avec impatience ; << ca commence : << Passant pres de chez lui -- >> >>

eng: "It's the first position in dancing." Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
fr: "<< C'est la premiere position lorsqu'on apprend a danser, >> dit Alice ; tout cela l'embarrassait fort, et il lui tardait de changer la conversation.

eng: "Yes, I think you'd better leave off," said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
fr: >> << Oui, je crois que vous feriez bien d'en rester la, >> dit le Griffon ; et Alice ne demanda pas mieux.

eng: "Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?"
fr: << Essaierons-nous une autre figure du Quadrille de Homards ?

eng: the Gryphon went on.
fr: >> continua le Griffon.

eng: "Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish, Game, or any other dish? Who would not give all else for two p ennyworth only of beautiful Soup? Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup? ~~~ Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! ~~~ Soo--oop of the e--e--evening, Beautiful, beauti--FUL SOUP!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:--
fr: La Fausse-Tortue poussa un profond soupir et commenca, d'une voix de temps en temps etouffee par les sanglots :

eng: "Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her '_Turtle Soup_,' will you, old fellow?"
fr: "<< Hum ! Chacun son gout. Chantez-lui << La Soupe a la Tortue, >> he ! camarade ! >>"

eng: "Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind," Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone,
fr: "<< Oh ! une chanson, je vous prie ; si la Fausse-Tortue veut bien avoir cette obligeance, >> repondit Alice, avec tant d'empressement que le Griffon dit d'un air un peu offense :"

eng: "Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?"
fr: "<< Ou bien, preferez-vous que la Fausse-Tortue vous chante quelque chose ? >>"

eng: "Chorus again!"
fr: "<< Bis au refrain !' "

eng: "Beautiful Soup, so rich and green, Waiting in a hot tureen! ~~~ Who for such dainties would not stoop? Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup! Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup! Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! ~~~ Soo--oop of the e--e--evening, Beautiful, beautiful Soup!"
fr: "<< O doux potage, O mets delicieux ! Ah ! ~~~ pour partage, Quoi de plus precieux ? Plonger dans ma soupiere Cette vaste cuillere Est un bonheur Qui me rejouit le coeur. << Gibier, volaille, Lievres, dindes, perdreaux, Rien qui te vaille, -- Pas meme les pruneaux ! Plonger dans ma soupiere Cette vaste cuillere Est un bonheur Qui me rejouit le coeur. >>"

eng: cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of "The trial's beginning!"
fr: >> cria le Griffon ; et la Fausse-Tortue venait de le reprendre, quand un cri, << Le proces va commencer !

eng: was heard in the distance.
fr: >> se fit entendre au loin.

eng: "Come on!"
fr: << Venez donc !

eng: "What trial is it?" Alice panted as she ran;
fr: << Qu'est-ce que c'est que ce proces ? >> demanda Alice hors d'haleine ;

eng: but the Gryphon only answered "Come on!"
fr: mais le Griffon se contenta de repondre : << Venez donc ! >>

eng: and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:-- "Soo--oop of the e--e--evening, Beautiful, beautiful Soup!"
fr: en courant de plus belle, tandis que leur parvenaient, de plus en plus faibles, apportees par la brise qui les poursuivait, ces paroles pleines de melancolie : << Plonger dans ma soupiere Cette vaste cuillere Est un bonheur Qui me rejouit le coeur. >>

eng: cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
fr: >> cria le Griffon ; et, prenant Alice par la main, il se mit a courir sans attendre la fin de la chanson.

eng: CHAPTER XI.
fr: CHAPITRE XI.

eng: Who Stole the Tarts?
fr: QUI A VOLE LES TARTES ?

eng: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them--all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards:
fr: Le Roi et la Reine de Coeur etaient assis sur leur trone, entoures d'une nombreuse assemblee : toutes sortes de petits oiseaux et d'autres betes, ainsi que le paquet de cartes tout entier.

eng: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him;
fr: Le Valet, charge de chaines, garde de chaque cote par un soldat, se tenait debout devant le trone,

eng: and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.
fr: et pres du roi se trouvait le Lapin Blanc, tenant d'une main une trompette et de l'autre un rouleau de parchemin.

eng: But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
fr: mais cela ne paraissait guere probable, aussi se mit-elle a regarder tout autour d'elle pour passer le temps.

eng: In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it:
fr: Au beau milieu de la salle etait une table sur laquelle on voyait un grand plat de tartes ;

eng: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them--
fr: ces tartes semblaient si bonnes que cela donna faim a Alice, rien que de les regarder.

eng: "I wish they'd get the trial done," she thought, "and hand round the refreshments!"
fr: << Je voudrais bien qu'on se depechat de finir le proces, >> pensa-t-elle, << et qu'on fit passer les rafraichissements, >>

eng: Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there.
fr: C'etait la premiere fois qu'Alice se trouvait dans une cour de justice, mais elle en avait lu des descriptions dans les livres, et elle fut toute contente de voir qu'elle savait le nom de presque tout ce qu'il y avait la.

eng: "That's the judge," she said to herself, "because of his great wig."
fr: << Ca, c'est le juge, >> se dit-elle ; << je le reconnais a sa grande perruque.

eng: The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
fr: >> Le juge, disons-le en passant, etait le Roi, et, comme il portait sa couronne par-dessus sa perruque (regardez le frontispice, si vous voulez savoir comment il s'etait arrange) il n'avait pas du tout l'air d'etre a son aise, et cela ne lui allait pas bien du tout.

eng: "And that's the jury-box," thought Alice, "and those twelve creatures," (she was obliged to say "creatures," you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) "I suppose they are the jurors." ~~~ She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. ~~~ However, "jury-men" would have done just as well.
fr: << Et ca, c'est le banc du jury, >> pensa Alice ; << et ces douze creatures >> (elle etait forcee de dire << creatures, >> vous comprenez, car quelques-uns etaient des betes et quelques autres des oiseaux), << je suppose que ce sont les jures ; >> elle se repeta ce dernier mot deux ou trois fois, car elle en etait assez fiere : pensant avec raison que bien peu de petites filles de son age savent ce que cela veut dire.

eng: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates.
fr: Les douze jures etaient tous tres-occupes a ecrire sur des ardoises.

eng: "What are they doing?"
fr: << Qu'est-ce qu'ils font la ?

eng: Alice whispered to the Gryphon.
fr: >> dit Alice a l'oreille du Griffon.

eng: "They can't have anything to put down yet, before the trial's begun."
fr: << Ils ne peuvent rien avoir a ecrire avant que le proces soit commence.

eng: "They're putting down their names," the Gryphon whispered in reply, "for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial."
fr: >> << Ils inscrivent leur nom, >> repondit de meme le Griffon, << de peur de l'oublier avant la fin du proces.

eng: "Stupid things!"
fr: >> << Les niais !

eng: Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, "Silence in the court!"
fr: >> s'ecria Alice d'un ton indigne, mais elle se retint bien vite, car le Lapin Blanc cria : << Silence dans l'auditoire !

eng: and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
fr: >> Et le Roi, mettant ses lunettes, regarda vivement autour de lui pour voir qui parlait.

eng: She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
fr: Ce fut si tot fait que le pauvre petit jure (c'etait Jacques, le lezard) ne pouvait pas s'imaginer ce qu'il etait devenu. Apres avoir cherche partout, il fut oblige d'ecrire avec un doigt tout le reste du jour, et cela etait fort inutile, puisque son doigt ne laissait aucune marque sur l'ardoise.

eng: This of course, Alice could _not_ stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away.
fr: Alice, vous le pensez bien, ne pouvait pas souffrir cela ; elle fit le tour de la salle, arriva derriere lui, et trouva bientot l'occasion d'enlever le crayon.

eng: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
fr: Un des jures avait un crayon qui grincait ;

eng: "A nice muddle their slates'll be in before the trial's over!" thought Alice.
fr: << Leurs ardoises seront dans un bel etat avant la fin du proces ! >> pensa Alice.

eng: Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down "stupid things!" on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn't know how to spell "stupid," and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him.
fr: Alice pouvait voir, aussi clairement que si elle eut regarde par-dessus leurs epaules, que tous les jures etaient en train d'ecrire << les niais >> sur leurs ardoises, et elle pouvait meme distinguer que l'un d'eux ne savait pas ecrire << niais >> et qu'il etait oblige de le demander a son voisin.

eng: "Herald, read the accusation!"
fr: << Heraut, lisez l'acte d'accusation !

eng: said the King.
fr: >> dit le Roi.

eng: '"Consider your verdict," the King said to the jury.'
fr: '<< Deliberez, >> dit le Roi aux jures.'

eng: '"Not yet, not yet!" the Rabbit hastily interrupted. "There's a great deal to come before that!"'
fr: '<< Pas encore, pas encore, >> interrompit vivement le Lapin ; << il y a bien des choses a faire auparavant ! >>'

eng: 'On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:-- "The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts, All on a summer day: The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts, And took them quite away!"'
fr: 'Sur ce, le Lapin Blanc sonna trois fois de la trompette, et puis, deroulant le parchemin, lut ainsi qu'il suit : << La Reine de Coeur fit des tartes, Un beau jour de printemps ; Le Valet de Coeur prit les tartes, Et s'en fut tout content ! >>'

eng: '"Call the first witness," said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, "First witness!"'
fr: '<< Appelez les temoins, >> dit le Roi ; et le Lapin Blanc sonna trois fois de la trompette, et cria : << Le premier temoin !'

eng: The first witness was the Hatter.
fr: >> Le premier temoin etait le Chapelier.

eng: He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other.
fr: Il entra, tenant d'une main une tasse de the et de l'autre une tartine de beurre.

eng: "I beg pardon, your Majesty," he began, "for bringing these in: but I hadn't quite finished my tea when I was sent for."
fr: << Pardon, Votre Majeste, >> dit-il, << si j'apporte cela ici ; je n'avais pas tout a fait fini de prendre mon the lorsqu'on est venu me chercher.

eng: "You ought to have finished," said the King. ~~~ "When did you begin?"
fr: >> << Vous auriez du avoir fini, >> dit le Roi ; << quand avez-vous commence ?

eng: The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse.
fr: >> Le Chapelier regarda le Lievre qui l'avait suivi dans la salle, bras dessus bras dessous avec le Loir.

eng: "Fourteenth of March, I _think_ it was," he said.
fr: << Le Quatorze Mars, je crois bien, >> dit-il.

eng: "Fifteenth," said the March Hare.
fr: "<< Le Quinze ! ~~~ >> dit le Lievre.

eng: "Write that down," the King said to the jury,
fr: "<< Notez cela, >> dit le Roi aux jures.

eng: and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
fr: Et les jures s'empresserent d'ecrire les trois dates sur leurs ardoises ; puis en firent l'addition, dont ils chercherent a reduire le total en francs et centimes.

eng: "Take off your hat," the King said to the Hatter.
fr: "<< Otez votre chapeau, >> dit le Roi au Chapelier.

eng: "Sixteenth," added the Dormouse.
fr: "<< Le Seize ! >> ajouta le Loir.

eng: "It isn't mine," said the Hatter.
fr: << Il n'est pas a moi, >> dit le Chapelier.

eng: "_Stolen!_" the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
fr: "<< Vole ! ~~~ >> s'ecria le Roi en se tournant du cote des jures, qui s'empresserent de prendre note du fait.

eng: "I keep them to sell," the Hatter added as an explanation;
fr: "<< Je les tiens en vente, >> ajouta le Chapelier, comme explication.

eng: "I've none of my own. I'm a hatter."
fr: "<< Je n'en ai pas a moi ; je suis chapelier. >>

eng: Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
fr: Ici la Reine mit ses lunettes, et se prit a regarder fixement le Chapelier, qui devint pale et tremblant.

eng: "Give your evidence," said the King; "and don't be nervous, or I'll have you executed on the spot."
fr: << Faites votre deposition, >> dit le Roi ; << et ne soyez pas agite ; sans cela je vous fais executer sur-le-champ.

eng: This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
fr: >> Cela ne parut pas du tout encourager le temoin ; il ne cessait de passer d'un pied sur l'autre en regardant la Reine d'un air inquiet, et, dans son trouble, il mordit dans la tasse et en enleva un grand morceau, au lieu de mordre dans la tartine de beurre.

eng: 'Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.'
fr: 'Juste a ce moment-la, Alice eprouva une etrange sensation qui l'embarrassa beaucoup, jusqu'a ce qu'elle se fut rendu compte de ce que c'etait. Elle recommencait a grandir, et elle pensa d'abord a se lever et a quitter la cour : mais, toute reflexion faite, elle se decida a rester ou elle etait, tant qu'il y aurait de la place pour elle.'

eng: '"I wish you wouldn't squeeze so." said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her. "I can hardly breathe."'
fr: '<< Ne poussez donc pas comme ca, >> dit le Loir ; << je puis a peine respirer. >>'

eng: '"I can't help it," said Alice very meekly: "I'm growing."'
fr: '<< Ce n'est pas de ma faute, >> dit Alice doucement ; << je grandis.'

eng: "You've no right to grow _here_," said the Dormouse.
fr: >> << Vous n'avez pas le droit de grandir ici, >> dit le Loir.

eng: "Don't talk nonsense," said Alice more boldly: "you know you're growing too."
fr: << Ne dites pas de sottises, >> repliqua Alice plus hardiment ; << vous savez bien que vous aussi vous grandissez.

eng: "Yes, but _I_ grow at a reasonable pace," said the Dormouse: "not in that ridiculous fashion."
fr: >> << Oui, mais je grandis raisonnablement, moi, >> dit le Loir ; << et non de cette facon ridicule.

eng: And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.
fr: >> Il se leva en faisant la mine, et passa de l'autre cote de la salle.

eng: All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, "Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!"
fr: Pendant tout ce temps-la, la Reine n'avait pas cesse de fixer les yeux sur le Chapelier, et, comme le Loir traversait la salle, elle dit a un des officiers du tribunal : << Apportez-moi la liste des chanteurs du dernier concert.

eng: on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
fr: >> Sur quoi, le malheureux Chapelier se mit a trembler si fortement qu'il en perdit ses deux souliers.

eng: "Give your evidence," the King repeated angrily, "or I'll have you executed, whether you're nervous or not."
fr: << Faites votre deposition, >> repeta le Roi en colere ; << ou bien je vous fais executer, que vous soyez trouble ou non !

eng: "I'm a poor man, your Majesty," the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, "--and I hadn't begun my tea--not above a week or so--and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin--and the twinkling of the tea--" "The twinkling of the _what?_" said the King.
fr: >> << Je suis un pauvre homme, Votre Majeste, >> fit le Chapelier d'une voix tremblante ; << et il n'y avait guere qu'une semaine ou deux que j'avais commence a prendre mon the, et avec ca les tartines devenaient si minces et les dragees du the -- >> << Les dragees de quoi ? ~~~ >> dit le Roi.

eng: "I deny it!" said the March Hare.
fr: << Je le nie ! >> cria le Lievre.

eng: "I'm a poor man," the Hatter went on, "and most things twinkled after that--only the March Hare said--"
fr: << Je suis un pauvre homme, >> continua le Chapelier ; << et les dragees et les autres choses me firent perdre la tete. Mais le Lievre dit -- >>

eng: "Of course twinkling begins with a T!" said the King sharply.
fr: << Je vous dis que dragee commence par un d ! >> cria le Roi vivement.

eng: "Do you take me for a dunce? Go on!"
fr: << Me prenez-vous pour un ane ? Continuez ! >>

eng: "He denies it," said the King: "leave out that part."'
fr: << Il le nie ! >> dit le Roi. << Passez la-dessus. ~~~ >>

eng: "It began with the tea," the Hatter replied.
fr: "<< Ca a commence par le the, >> repondit le Chapelier.

eng: (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: << Eh bien !'

eng: "You did!" said the Hatter.
fr: << C'est vrai ! ~~~ >> cria le Chapelier.

eng: "I didn't!" the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
fr: << C'est faux ! >> s'ecria le Lievre se depechant de l'interrompre.

eng: "Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said--" the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
fr: dans tous les cas, le Loir dit -- >> continua le Chapelier, regardant autour de lui pour voir s'il nierait aussi ; mais le Loir ne nia rien, car il dormait profondement.

eng: "But what did the Dormouse say?" one of the jury asked.
fr: "<< Mais, que dit le Loir ? >> demanda un des jures.

eng: "That I can't remember," said the Hatter.
fr: "<< C'est ce que je ne peux pas me rappeler, >> dit le Chapelier."

eng: "After that," continued the Hatter, "I cut some more bread-and-butter--"
fr: "<< Apres cela, >> continua le Chapelier, << je me coupai d'autres tartines de beurre. >>

eng: "You _must_ remember," remarked the King, "or I'll have you executed."
fr: << Il faut absolument que vous vous le rappeliez, >> fit observer le Roi ; << ou bien je vous fais executer.

eng: The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee.
fr: >> Le malheureux Chapelier laissa tomber sa tasse et sa tartine de beurre, et mit un genou en terre.

eng: "You're a _very_ poor _speaker_," said the King.
fr: >> Vous etes un tres-pauvre orateur, >> dit le Roi.

eng: "I'm a poor man, your Majesty," he began.
fr: >> Je suis un pauvre homme, Votre Majeste ! >> commenca-t-il.

eng: Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court.
fr: Ici un des cochons d'Inde applaudit, et fut immediatement reprime par un des huissiers.

eng: (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done.
fr: (Comme ce mot est assez difficile, je vais vous expliquer comment cela se fit.

eng: They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)
fr: Ils avaient un grand sac de toile qui se fermait a l'aide de deux ficelles attachees a l'ouverture ; dans ce sac ils firent glisser le cochon d'Inde la tete la premiere, puis ils s'assirent dessus.)

eng: "I'm glad I've seen that done," thought Alice.
fr: << Je suis contente d'avoir vu cela, >> pensa Alice.

eng: "If that's all you know about it, you may stand down," continued the King.
fr: "<< Si c'est la tout ce que vous savez de l'affaire, vous pouvez vous prosterner, >> continua le Roi.

eng: "I've so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, "There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court," and I never understood what it meant till now."
fr: "<< J'ai souvent lu dans les journaux, a la fin des proces : << Il se fit quelques tentatives d'applaudissements qui furent bientot reprimees par les huissiers, >> et je n'avais jamais compris jusqu'a present ce que cela voulait dire. >>

eng: "I can't go no lower," said the Hatter: "I'm on the floor, as it is."
fr: "<< Je ne puis pas me prosterner plus bas que cela, >> dit le Chapelier ; << je suis deja par terre.

eng: "Then you may _sit_ down," the King replied.
fr: >> << Alors asseyez-vous, >> repondit le Roi.

eng: Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
fr: Ici l'autre cochon d'Inde applaudit et fut reprime.

eng: "Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!"
fr: << Bon, cela met fin aux cochons d'Inde !

eng: thought Alice.
fr: >> pensa Alice.

eng: "Now we shall get on better."
fr: << Maintenant ca va mieux aller.

eng: "I'd rather finish my tea," said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
fr: >> << J'aimerais bien aller finir de prendre mon the, >> dit le Chapelier, en lancant un regard inquiet sur la Reine, qui lisait la liste des chanteurs.

eng: "You may go," said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on. "
fr: << Vous pouvez vous retirer, >> dit le Roi ; et le Chapelier se hata de quitter la cour, sans meme prendre le temps de mettre ses souliers.

eng: "Give your evidence," said the King.
fr: << Faites votre deposition, >> dit le Roi.

eng: "Shan't," said the cook.
fr: << Non ! ~~~ >> dit la cuisiniere.

eng: She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
fr: elle tenait la poivriere a la main, et Alice devina qui c'etait, meme avant qu'elle entrat dans la salle, en voyant eternuer, tout a coup et tous a la fois, les gens qui se trouvaient pres de la porte.

eng: The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit,
fr: Le Roi regarda d'un air inquiet le Lapin Blanc,

eng: The next witness was the Duchess's cook.
fr: L'autre temoin, c'etait la cuisiniere de la Duchesse ;

eng: who said in a low voice, "Your Majesty must cross-examine _this_ witness."'
fr: qui lui dit a voix basse : << Il faut que Votre Majeste interroge ce temoin-la contradictoirement.'

eng: "Call the next witness!"
fr: "<< Appelez un autre temoin, >> dit le Roi.

eng: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.
fr: mais le Chapelier etait deja bien loin avant que l'huissier arrivat a la porte.

eng: "--and just take his head off outside," the Queen added to one of the officers:
fr: "<< Et coupez-lui la tete dehors, >> ajouta la Reine, s'adressant a un des huissiers ;

eng: said the King.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well, if I must, I must," the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, "What are tarts made of?"
fr: >> << Puisqu'il le faut, il le faut, >> dit le Roi, d'un air triste ; et, apres avoir croise les bras et fronce les sourcils en regardant la cuisiniere, au point que les yeux lui etaient presque completement rentres dans la tete, il dit d'une voix creuse : << De quoi les tartes sont-elles faites ?

eng: "Here!" cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
fr: << Voila ! ~~~ >> cria Alice, oubliant tout a fait dans le trouble du moment combien elle avait grandi depuis quelques instants, et elle se leva si brusquement qu'elle accrocha le banc des jures avec le bord de sa robe, et le renversa, avec tous ses occupants, sur la tete de la foule qui se trouvait au-dessous, et on les vit se debattant de tous cotes, comme les poissons rouges du vase qu'elle se rappelait avoir renverse par accident la semaine precedente.

eng: Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name "Alice!"
fr: Imaginez sa surprise quand le Lapin Blanc cria, du plus fort de sa petite voix criarde : << Alice ! >>

eng: Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like, "--for they haven't got much evidence _yet_," she said to herself.
fr: Alice regardait le Lapin Blanc tandis qu'il tournait la liste dans ses doigts, curieuse de savoir quel serait l'autre temoin. ~~~ << Car les depositions ne prouvent pas grand'chose jusqu'a present, >> se dit-elle.

eng: And he added in an undertone to the Queen, "Really, my dear, _you_ must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!"
fr: et il ajouta a voix basse en s'adressant a la Reine : << Vraiment, mon amie, il faut que vous interrogiez cet autre temoin ; cela me fait trop mal au front ! >>

eng: "Call the next witness."
fr: << Appelez le troisieme temoin ; >>

eng: "Behead that Dormouse! Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his whiskers!"
fr: << Coupez la tete a ce Loir ! Mettez ce Loir a la porte ! Reprimez-le, pincez-le, arrachez-lui ses moustaches ! >>

eng: For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.
fr: Pendant quelques instants, toute la cour fut sens dessus dessous pour mettre le Loir a la porte ; et, quand le calme fut retabli, la cuisiniere avait disparu.

eng: "Collar that Dormouse," the Queen shrieked out.
fr: << Saisissez ce Loir au collet ! >> cria la Reine.

eng: "Treacle," said a sleepy voice behind her.
fr: << De melasse, >> dit une voix endormie derriere elle.

eng: "Pepper, mostly," said the cook.
fr: '>> << De poivre principalement ! >> dit la cuisiniere.

eng: "Oh, I _beg_ your pardon!" she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.
fr: << Oh ! je vous demande bien pardon ! >> s'ecria-t-elle toute confuse, et elle se mit a les ramasser bien vite, car l'accident arrive aux poissons rouges lui trottait dans la tete, et elle avait une idee vague qu'il fallait les ramasser tout de suite et les remettre sur les bancs, sans quoi ils mourraient.

eng: "Never mind!" said the King, with an air of great relief.
fr: << Cela ne fait rien, >> dit le Roi, comme soulage d'un grand poids.

eng: "The trial cannot proceed," said the King in a very grave voice, "until all the jurymen are back in their proper places--_all_," he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.
fr: << Le proces ne peut continuer, >> dit le Roi d'une voix grave, << avant que les jures soient tous a leurs places ; tous ! ~~~ >> repeta-t-il avec emphase en regardant fixement Alice.

eng: CHAPTER XII. Alice's Evidence
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move.
fr: Alice regarda le banc des jures, et vit que dans son empressement elle y avait place le Lezard la tete en bas, et le pauvre petit etre remuait la queue d'une triste facon, dans l'impossibilite de se redresser ; elle l'eut bientot retourne et replace convenablement.

eng: She soon got it out again, and put it right; "not that it signifies much," she said to herself; "I should think it would be _quite_ as much use in the trial one way up as the other."
fr: << Non que cela soit bien important, >> se dit-elle, << car je pense qu'il serait tout aussi utile au proces la tete en bas qu'autrement.

eng: As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.
fr: >> Sitot que les jures se furent un peu remis de la secousse, qu'on eut retrouve et qu'on leur eut rendu leurs ardoises et leurs crayons, ils se mirent fort diligemment a ecrire l'histoire de l'accident, a l'exception du Lezard, qui paraissait trop accable pour faire autre chose que demeurer la bouche ouverte, les yeux fixes sur le plafond de la salle.

eng: "What do you know about this business?" the King said to Alice.
fr: "<< Que savez-vous de cette affaire-la ? >> demanda le Roi a Alice.

eng: "Nothing," said Alice.
fr: "<< Rien, >> repondit-elle."

eng: "Nothing _whatever?_" persisted the King.
fr: << Rien absolument ? ~~~ >> insista le Roi.

eng: "Nothing whatever," said Alice.
fr: << Rien absolument, >> dit Alice.

eng: "That's very important," the King said, turning to the jury.
fr: << Voila qui est tres-important, >> dit le Roi, se tournant vers les jures.

eng: They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted: "_Un_important, your Majesty means, of course," he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.
fr: Ils allaient ecrire cela sur leurs ardoises quand le Lapin Blanc interrompant : << Peu important, veut dire Votre Majeste, sans doute, >> dit-il d'un ton tres-respectueux, mais en froncant les sourcils et en lui faisant des grimaces.

eng: "You are," said the King.
fr: << Si fait, >> dit le Roi.

eng: "Nearly two miles high," added the Queen.
fr: << Pres de deux milles, >> ajouta la Reine.

eng: and went on to himself in an undertone, "important--unimportant--unimportant--important--" as if he were trying which word sounded best.
fr: Et il continua de repeter a demi-voix : << Tres-important, peu important, peu important, tres-important ; >> comme pour essayer lequel des deux etait le mieux sonnant.

eng: "_I'm_ not a mile high," said Alice.
fr: << Je n'ai pas un mille de haut, >> dit-elle.

eng: Everybody looked at Alice.
fr: Tout le monde regarda Alice.

eng: and read out from his book, "Rule Forty-two. _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_."
fr: et lut sur son carnet : << Regle Quarante-deux : Toute personne ayant une taille de plus d'un mille de haut devra quitter la cour. >>

eng: Some of the jury wrote it down "important," and some "unimportant."
fr: Quelques-uns des jures ecrivirent << tres-important, >> d'autres, << peu important. >>

eng: At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out "Silence!"
fr: A ce moment-la, le Roi, qui pendant quelque temps avait ete fort occupe a ecrire dans son carnet, cria : << Silence ! >>

eng: "but it doesn't matter a bit," she thought to herself.
fr: << Mais cela ne fait absolument rien, >> pensa-t-elle.

eng: Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates;
fr: Alice voyait tout cela, car elle etait assez pres d'eux pour regarder sur leurs ardoises.

eng: "_Un_important, of course, I meant," the King hastily said,
fr: "<< Peu important, bien entendu, c'est ce que je voulais dire, >> repliqua le Roi avec empressement.

eng: "Well, I shan't go, at any rate," said Alice: "besides, that's not a regular rule: you invented it just now."
fr: << Eh bien ! ~~~ je ne sortirai pas quand meme ; d'ailleurs cette regle n'est pas d'usage, vous venez de l'inventer.

eng: "It's the oldest rule in the book," said the King.
fr: >> << C'est la regle la plus ancienne qu'il y ait dans le livre, >> dit le Roi.

eng: "Then it ought to be Number One," said Alice.
fr: << Alors elle devrait porter le numero Un.

eng: The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily.
fr: >> Le Roi devint pale et ferma vivement son carnet.

eng: "Consider your verdict," he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.
fr: << Deliberez, >> dit-il aux jures d'une voix faible et tremblante.

eng: "There's more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty," said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; "this paper has just been picked up."
fr: << Il y a d'autres depositions a recevoir, s'il plait a Votre Majeste, >> dit le Lapin, se levant precipitamment ; << on vient de ramasser ce papier.

eng: "What's in it?"
fr: >> << Qu'est-ce qu'il y a dedans ?

eng: said the Queen.
fr: >> dit la Reine.

eng: "I haven't opened it yet," said the White Rabbit, "but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to--to somebody."
fr: << Je ne l'ai pas encore ouvert, >> dit le Lapin Blanc ; << mais on dirait que c'est une lettre ecrite par l'accuse a -- a quelqu'un.

eng: "It must have been that," said the King, "unless it was written to nobody, which isn't usual, you know."
fr: >> << Cela doit etre ainsi, >> dit le Roi, << a moins qu'elle ne soit ecrite a personne, ce qui n'est pas ordinaire, vous comprenez.

eng: "Who is it directed to?"
fr: >> << A qui est-elle adressee ?

eng: said one of the jurymen.
fr: >> dit un des jures.

eng: "It isn't directed at all," said the White Rabbit; "in fact, there's nothing written on the _outside_."
fr: << Elle n'est pas adressee du tout, >> dit le Lapin Blanc ; << au fait, il n'y a rien d'ecrit a l'exterieur.

eng: "No, they're not," said the White Rabbit, "and that's the queerest thing about it."
fr: << Non, >> dit le Lapin Blanc, << et c'est ce qu'il y a de plus drole. >>

eng: (The jury all looked puzzled.)
fr: (Les jures eurent tous l'air fort embarrasse.)

eng: "Are they in the prisoner's handwriting?" asked another of the jurymen.
fr: << Est-ce l'ecriture de l'accuse ? >> demanda un autre jure.

eng: He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added "It isn't a letter, after all: it's a set of verses."
fr: Il deplia le papier tout en parlant et ajouta : << Ce n'est pas une lettre, apres tout ; c'est une piece de vers. >>

eng: "He must have imitated somebody else's hand," said the King.
fr: << Il faut qu'il ait imite l'ecriture d'un autre, >> dit le Roi.

eng: (The jury all brightened up again.)
fr: (Les jures reprirent l'air serein.)

eng: "Please your Majesty," said the Knave, "I didn't write it, and they can't prove I did: there's no name signed at the end."
fr: << Pardon, Votre Majeste, >> dit le Valet, << ce n'est pas moi qui ai ecrit cette lettre, et on ne peut pas prouver que ce soit moi ; il n'y a pas de signature.

eng: "If you didn't sign it," said the King, "that only makes the matter worse. ~~~ You _must_ have meant some mischief, or else you'd have signed your name like an honest man."
fr: >> << Si vous n'avez pas signe, >> dit le Roi, << cela ne fait qu'empirer la chose ; il faut absolument que vous ayez eu de mauvaises intentions, sans cela vous auriez signe, comme un honnete homme.

eng: There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.
fr: >> La-dessus tout le monde battit des mains ; c'etait la premiere reflexion vraiment bonne que le Roi eut faite ce jour-la.

eng: "Read them," said the King.
fr: "<< Lisez ces vers, >> dit le Roi."

eng: "Why, you don't even know what they're about!"
fr: "<< Vous ne savez meme pas ce dont il s'agit. >>"

eng: "It proves nothing of the sort!" said Alice.
fr: "<< Cela ne prouve rien, >> dit Alice."

eng: "That proves his guilt," said the Queen.
fr: "<< Cela prouve sa culpabilite, >> dit la Reine."

eng: The White Rabbit put on his spectacles.
fr: Le Lapin Blanc mit ses lunettes.

eng: "Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?"
fr: << Par ou commencerai-je, s'il plait a Votre Majeste ?

eng: he asked.
fr: >> demanda-t-il.

eng: And mentioned me to him:
fr: Afin de lui pouvoir parler,

eng: You gave us three or more;
fr: Combien donc en recevrons-nous ?

eng: They all returned from him to you,
fr: Toutes revinrent d'eux a vous.

eng: Though they were mine before.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: If I or she should chance to be
fr: Si vous ou moi, dans cette affaire,

eng: Involved in this affair,
fr: Etions par trop embarrasses,

eng: He trusts to you to set them free,
fr: Prions qu'il nous laisse, confrere,

eng: What would become of you?
fr: Ou gare les coups de balai !

eng: (We know it to be true):
fr: (Nous savons fort bien que c'est vrai !)

eng: He sent them word I had not gone
fr: Bientot il leur envoya dire

eng: But said I could not swim.
fr: Que je ne savais pas nager !

eng: Exactly as we were.
fr: Tous deux comme il nous a trouves.

eng: She gave me a good character,
fr: Et qu'elle assura, la cruelle,

eng: "They told me you had been to her,
fr: "<< On m'a dit que tu fus chez elle

eng: These were the verses the White Rabbit read:--
fr: Voici les vers que lut le Lapin Blanc :

eng: "Begin at the beginning," the King said gravely, "and go on till you come to the end: then stop."
fr: "<< Commencez par le commencement, >> dit gravement le Roi, << et continuez jusqu'a ce que vous arriviez a la fin ; la, vous vous arreterez. >>

eng: I gave her one, they gave him two,
fr: J'en donnai trois, elle en prit une ;

eng: (Before she had this fit)
fr: (Avant que de ses nerfs l'acces

eng: An obstacle that came between
fr: Ne bouleversat l'inhumaine,)

eng: Him, and ourselves, and it.
fr: Trompes tous trois avec succes.

eng: Don't let him know she liked them best,
fr: Cachez-lui qu'elle les prefere ;

eng: For this must ever be
fr: Car ce doit etre, par ma foi,

eng: If she should push the matter on,
fr: Qu'il ne faudrait pas en medire,

eng: A secret, kept from all the rest,
fr: (Et sera toujours, je l'espere)

eng: Between yourself and me."
fr: Un secret entre vous et moi.'

eng: My notion was that you had been
fr: Vous les avez, j'en suis certaine,

eng: "That's the most important piece of evidence we've heard yet," said the King, rubbing his hands; "so now let the jury--" "If any one of them can explain it," said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn't a bit afraid of interrupting him,) "I'll give him sixpence.
fr: >> << Voila la piece de conviction la plus importante que nous ayons eue jusqu'a present, >> dit le Roi en se frottant les mains ; << ainsi, que le jury maintenant -- -- >> << S'il y a un seul des jures qui puisse l'expliquer, >> dit Alice (elle etait devenue si grande dans ces derniers instants qu'elle n'avait plus du tout peur de l'interrompre), << je lui donne une piece de dix sous.

eng: _I_ don't believe there's an atom of meaning in it."
fr: Je ne crois pas qu'il y ait un atome de sens commun la-dedans.

eng: The jury all wrote down on their slates, "_She_ doesn't believe there's an atom of meaning in it," but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
fr: >> Tous les jures ecrivirent sur leurs ardoises : << Elle ne croit pas qu'il y ait un atome de sens commun la-dedans, >> mais aucun d'eux ne tenta d'expliquer la piece de vers.

eng: "--_said I could not swim_--"
fr: Que je ne savais pas nager !

eng: "you can't swim, can you?" he added, turning to the Knave.
fr: >> Vous ne savez pas nager, n'est-ce pas ? >> ajouta-t-il en se tournant vers le Valet.

eng: "And yet I don't know," he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; "I seem to see some meaning in them, after all."
fr: << et cependant je ne sais pas trop, >> continua-t-il en etalant la piece de vers sur ses genoux et les regardant d'un oeil ; << il me semble que j'y vois quelque chose, apres tout.

eng: "If there's no meaning in it," said the King, "that saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn't try to find any."
fr: "<< Si elle ne signifie rien, >> dit le Roi, << cela nous epargne un monde d'ennuis, vous comprenez ; car il est inutile d'en chercher l'explication ;

eng: The Knave shook his head sadly.
fr: Le Valet secoua la tete tristement.

eng: "Do I look like it?" ~~~ he said.
fr: << En ai-je l'air, >> dit-il.

eng: "why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know--"
fr: justement, c'est la ce qu'il fit des tartes, vous comprenez. ~~~

eng: "that's the jury, of course--'_I gave her one, they gave him two_--'"
fr: C'est le jury qui dit cela, bien sur ! ~~~ << J'en donnai trois, elle en prit une ; >>

eng: "All right, so far," said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: "'_We know it to be true_--'"
fr: << Jusqu'ici c'est bien, >> dit le Roi ; et il continua de marmotter tout bas, << << Nous savons fort bien que c'est vrai. >>

eng: (Which he certainly did _not_, being made entirely of cardboard.)
fr: (Non, certainement, il n'en avait pas l'air, etant fait tout entier de carton.)

eng: "But, it goes on '_they all returned from him to you_,'" said Alice.
fr: >> << Mais vient ensuite : << Toutes revinrent d'eux a vous, >> >> dit Alice.

eng: "Why, there they are!"
fr: << Tiens, mais les voici !

eng: "Then again--'_before she had this fit_--'"
fr: "et encore : << Avant que de ses nerfs l'acces. >>"

eng: "said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table."
fr: ">> dit le Roi d'un air de triomphe, montrant du doigt les tartes qui etaient sur la table."

eng: "Nothing can be clearer than _that_."
fr: "<< Il n'y a rien de plus clair que cela ; "

eng: "you never had fits, my dear, I think?"
fr: "Vous n'avez jamais eu d'attaques de nerfs, je crois, mon epouse ?"

eng: he said to the Queen.
fr: >> dit-il a la Reine.

eng: "Never!"
fr: << Jamais !

eng: said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke.
fr: >> dit la Reine d'un air furieux en jetant un encrier a la tete du Lezard.

eng: "The idea of having the sentence first!"
fr: << Quelle idee de vouloir prononcer l'arret d'abord ! >>

eng: "Let the jury consider their verdict," the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.
fr: << Que le jury delibere, >> ajouta le Roi, pour a peu pres la vingtieme fois ce jour-la.

eng: "Stuff and nonsense!" said Alice loudly.
fr: << Cela n'a pas de bon sens ! >> dit tout haut Alice.

eng: "It's a pun!" the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed,
fr: << C'est un calembour, >> ajouta le Roi d'un ton de colere ; et tout le monde se mit a rire.

eng: "Hold your tongue!" said the Queen, turning purple.
fr: << Taisez-vous, >> dit la Reine, devenant pourpre de colere.

eng: "I won't!" said Alice.
fr: << Je ne me tairai pas, >> dit Alice.

eng: "Then the words don't _fit_ you," said the King, looking round the court with a smile.
fr: << Non, mon epouse, vous avez trop bon air, >> dit le Roi, promenant son regard tout autour de la salle et souriant.

eng: There was a dead silence.
fr: Il se fit un silence de mort.

eng: "Sentence first--verdict afterwards."
fr: << l'arret d'abord, on deliberera apres. >>

eng: (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)
fr: (Le malheureux Jacques avait cesse d'ecrire sur son ardoise avec un doigt, car il s'etait apercu que cela ne faisait aucune marque ; mais il se remit bien vite a l'ouvrage en se servant de l'encre qui lui decoulait le long de la figure, aussi longtemps qu'il y en eut.)

eng: "Off with her head!"
fr: << Qu'on lui coupe la tete !

eng: "No, no!" said the Queen.
fr: << Non, non, >> dit la Reine,

eng: the Queen shouted at the top of her voice.
fr: >> hurla la Reine de toutes ses forces.

eng: '"Who cares for you?" said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.) "You're nothing but a pack of cards!"'
fr: '<< On se moque bien de vous, >> dit Alice (elle avait alors atteint toute sa grandeur naturelle). << Vous n'etes qu'un paquet de cartes !''

eng: 'Nobody moved.'
fr: 'Personne ne bougea.'

eng: At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
fr: >> La-dessus tout le paquet sauta en l'air et retomba en tourbillonnant sur elle ; Alice poussa un petit cri, moitie de peur, moitie de colere, et essaya de les repousser ; elle se trouva etendue sur le gazon, la tete sur les genoux de sa soeur, qui ecartait doucement de sa figure les feuilles mortes tombees en voltigeant du haut des arbres.

eng: "It _was_ a curious dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it's getting late."'
fr: << Certes, c'est un bien drole de reve ; mais maintenant courez a la maison prendre le the ; il se fait tard.'

eng: "Wake up, Alice dear!" said her sister;
fr: "<< Reveillez-vous, chere Alice ! >> lui dit sa soeur.

eng: "Why, what a long sleep you've had!"
fr: "<< Quel long somme vous venez de faire ! >>

eng: "Oh, I've had such a curious dream!" said Alice,
fr: << Oh ! ~~~ j'ai fait un si drole de reve, >> dit Alice ;

eng: and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about;
fr: et elle raconta a sa soeur, autant qu'elle put s'en souvenir, toutes les etranges aventures que vous venez de lire ;

eng: and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said,
fr: et, quand elle eut fini son recit, sa soeur lui dit en l'embrassant :

eng: So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.
fr: >> Alice se leva donc et s'eloigna en courant, pensant le long du chemin, et avec raison, quel reve merveilleux elle venait de faire.

eng: But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:-- First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers--she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that _would_ always get into her eyes--and still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister's dream.
fr: Mais sa soeur demeura assise tranquillement, tout comme elle l'avait laissee, la tete appuyee sur la main, contemplant le coucher du soleil et pensant a la petite Alice et a ses merveilleuses aventures ; si bien qu'elle aussi se mit a rever, en quelque sorte ; et voici son reve : -- D'abord elle reva de la petite Alice personnellement : -- les petites mains de l'enfant etaient encore jointes sur ses genoux, et ses yeux vifs et brillants plongeaient leur regard dans les siens.

eng: The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by--
fr: Les longues herbes bruissaient a ses pieds sous les pas precipites du Lapin Blanc ;

eng: perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago:
fr: et peut-etre meme en leur contant le songe du Pays des Merveilles du temps jadis :

eng: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make _their_ eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale,
fr: et reunissant autour d'elle d'autres petits enfants dont elle ferait briller les yeux vifs et curieux au recit de bien des aventures etranges,

eng: and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood:
fr: elle se la representa conservant, jusque dans l'age mur, le coeur simple et aimant de son enfance,

eng: Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman;
fr: Enfin elle se representa cette meme petite soeur, dans l'avenir, devenue elle aussi une grande personne ;

eng: while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle's heavy sobs.
fr: tandis que le beuglement des bestiaux dans le lointain remplacerait les lourds sanglots de la Fausse-Tortue.

eng: and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard--
fr: l'eternuement du bebe, le cri du Griffon et tous les autres bruits etranges ne seraient plus, elle le savait bien, que les clameurs confuses d'une cour de ferme,

eng: and the Queen's shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy--
fr: et elle reconnaitrait les cris aigus de la Reine dans la voix percante du petit berger ;

eng: the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells,
fr: le bruit des tasses deviendrait le tintement des clochettes au cou des moutons,

eng: She heard even the sound of her voice; she saw that peculiar little toss of the head by which she threw back the stray hairs that were always getting into her eyes; and, as she listened or seemed to listen, everything around her quickened and became peopled with the strange creatures of her young sisters dream.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds--
fr: les herbes ne bruiraient plus alors que sous le souffle du vent, et l'eau de la mare ne murmurerait plus qu'au balancement des roseaux ;

eng: So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland,
fr: C'est ainsi qu'elle demeura assise, les yeux fermes, et se croyant presque dans le Pays des Merveilles,

eng: mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.
fr: en se melant aux sanglots que poussait au loin la malheureuse Fausse-Tortue.

eng: once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard's slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air,
fr: une fois encore la voix criarde du Griffon, le grincement du crayon d'ardoise du Lezard, et les cris etouffes des cochons d'Inde mis dans le sac par ordre de la cour, remplissaient les airs,

eng: while plates and dishes crashed around it--
fr: tandis que les assiettes et les plats se brisaient autour de lui ;

eng: once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess's knee,
fr: Une fois encore l'enfant-porc eternuait sur les genoux de la Duchesse,

eng: and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution--
fr: et la voix percante de la Reine envoyant a la mort ses malheureux invites.

eng: she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal,
fr: elle entendait le bruit des tasses, tandis que le Lievre et ses amis prenaient leur repas qui ne finissait jamais,

eng: the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool--
fr: la Souris effrayee faisait clapoter l'eau en traversant la mare voisine ;

eng: though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality--
fr: bien qu'elle sut qu'elle n'avait qu'a rouvrir les yeux pour que tout fut change en une triste realite :

eng: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days. THE END
fr: elle la voyait partager leurs petits chagrins et trouver plaisir a leurs innocentes joies, se rappelant sa propre enfance et les heureux jours d'ete.
